shortVersion.title: THE SHORT VERSION
shortVersion.description:
Builder and operator who learned sales by necessity. 18+ years solving technical problems for real businesses - from implementing EMC storage systems at Volkswagen to building complete digital infrastructure for a 500-employee manufacturing company. Never lost a customer because I focus on actually fixing things rather than just talking about solutions.

Built and scaled my own businesses while co-managing a 20-person pharmacy operation. As a tech enthusiast with coding experience and sales expertise who loves to teach, I'm ready to help technical teams bridge the gap between building and selling.

myValues.title: My Values as a Developer & Sales Professional
myValues.intro:
What drives me in tech and business:
Three core principles:

reasons.title: Build First, Sell What Works
reasons.content: I've learned that the best sales come from deeply understanding what you've built. As someone who codes and sells, I bridge the gap between 'it works' and 'here's why you need it.' Being professional without being boring is the sweet spot I aim for.

reasons.title: Teaching is the Best Learning
reasons.content: After years of being a one-person show, I've discovered that teaching others what I know forces me to truly understand it myself. My random mix of skills (talking to people, fixing things that break, explaining complex tech simply) becomes most valuable when I'm helping others level up.

reasons.title: Scale Through Collaboration
reasons.content: I've gotten comfortable being the person everyone comes to when stuff breaks. Now I want to work with teams building at scales that make my current problems look quaint - millions of events, thousands of users, architectural challenges I haven't even discovered yet.

myValues.closing: As a tech enthusiast with coding experience and sales expertise who loves to teach, I thrive when helping technical teams understand their users and helping users understand technical products. I've lived through the exact frustrations that come from cobbling together tools, so I can authentically connect with both builders and buyers.

achievements.title: Achievements
items: Grew marketing agency to ‚Ç¨240K+ ARR while co-managing 20-employee pharmacy
Scaled client relationships from ‚Ç¨300/month to ‚Ç¨5K/month through problem-solving focus
Zero customer churn in 3+ years by prioritizing customer success over sales

content.bio:
I started off as a bad implementation specialist at EMC, became a worse startup developer at Northbit, then somehow bootstrapped a marketing agency on the side to make some money. I wasn't particularly good at any of it.

After realizing I kept my agency too small on purpose and had three kids to think about, my wife took over her family's pharmacy and I ended up handling the business side - finances, IT for 25 workstations, marketing, and helping manage 20 employees while she focused on the pharmacy work. Meanwhile I grew my marketing agency to ‚Ç¨240K+ ARR. We learned how to grow relationships from ‚Ç¨300/month to ‚Ç¨5K/month by actually solving problems instead of just selling services.

I started building my own event management platform in February 2025 as a way to inject myself into the startup scene in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern and branch out to Berlin. Everyone needs events, so I figured it was a good entry point. As a tech enthusiast with coding experience and sales expertise who loves to teach, I'm always looking for opportunities to help teams build better products.

I live in Pasewalk, Germany but travel back to Northern California once or twice a year (3-4 weeks) to connect with family and get some proper California sun.

readme.intro:
I'm from Auburn, California, now living in Pasewalk, Germany (my wife's hometown). I travel back to Northern California once a year for at least three or four weeks, sometimes twice a year in February or over Easter holidays, connecting back to my family and spending time in the California sun.

I started off as a bad implementation specialist at EMC, became a worse startup developer at Northbit, bootstrapped a marketing agency that I kept too small on purpose, somehow ended up co-running a pharmacy with 20 employees, and now I'm ready for new challenges in the tech world.

I tend to work 8am to 5pm, dinner break, sauna (this is critical), then three nights a week another 9-11pm shift.

responsibilities.title: Areas of responsibility (if you'll have me)
items: Help technical teams realize what becomes possible when their tools actually work together
Bridge the gap between complex technical capabilities and real business outcomes
Be the person teams call when they need someone who actually understands both the code and the business

quirks.title: Quirks
items: I hop around a lot in conversations - working on "reading the room" because sometimes random creative discussions are exactly what's needed, but when focused efficient conversations are required, I like to make notes and keep a short agenda, which keeps me from wandering.

I've evolved toward doing 90-minute bouts of uninterrupted deep work, with meetings and comms squeezed into 5-15 minute coffee/walk breaks between. Longer meetings are fine when needed, but usually aren't in my experience.

I take things too seriously sometimes. I don't take myself too seriously, but I do take work too seriously. The best flow comes from me being useful and getting things done well - I like to tone down my ego and have no problem admitting when I'm wrong. Ego is sometimes useful when you need to make a point, but I like to err on the side of less ego. I don't need to take credit for things. I just like to be useful. Obviously, I appreciate when people appreciate my work, but it's all about just getting shit done.

values.title: What I value
items: Being useful to others. I'd rather have mistakes than analysis paralysis.
Async work is gold.
Initiative - colleagues who solve things on their own instead of waiting for permission.
The sauna - that's where I literally let the steam off and stay emotionally stable.

help.title: How I can help you
items: I'm the person people come to for everything they can't solve on their own. Since I own my own business and help run my wife's pharmacy, if employees can't do it, I do it.
I'm naturally good at mediating conflicts - I go into fair, emotionally neutral mediator mode.
I can help you figure out what's actually worth your time vs. what just feels urgent.

helpMe.title: How you can help me
items: Take initiative. Do things. I'd rather course-correct than steer from scratch.
Be direct about what's working and what isn't.
Help me understand where I fit best - I'm open to wherever you think I'd be most useful.

personal.title: Personal
items: Weekends are sacred family time.
I practice Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu 2-3 times a week (would do it daily if I could - I'm hooked).
Working toward being more nomad-ready, though the kids love school too much to homeschool them.

strategy.title: Personal strategy
items: Two north stars guide everything:
1. My definition of freedom: do what I want, when I want, with the people I want, wherever I want
2. If it's not a HELL YES, then it's a NO
strategy.footer: Living a "HELL YES" life means if I hesitate for even a second on a decision, that hesitation tells me everything.
